newsitem.title: GERMANY: Germany's Otto Versand, Tellit sign insurance deal.
newsitem.headline: Germany's Otto Versand, Tellit sign insurance deal.

text.p: German direct-selling insurer Tellit, which is part of the Colonia group, and major mail order firm Otto-Versand have signed a co-operation agreement covering sales of insurance policies to Otto customers, both companies said.

Under the deal, Tellit secured access to more than five million Otto customers. With a group turnover of 12.5 billion marks in 1995, Hamburg-based Otto is one of the world's largest mail order companies.
This week, Otto sent a letter to 500,000 customers, promising up to 30 percent lower auto insurance costs.

Otto spokesman Detlev von Livonius said that the first mailshot was a test. "However, we expect a long-term cooperation." Otto was not acting as a broker for Tellit. "We are doing all mailings ourselves. We would not give our addresses to anyone," he added.

Tellit chief executive Klaus Sticker said that both companies would divide the profit from the operation, after deducting the costs. "In normal mailings, we would expect returns between 1.0 and 3.5 percent," he said. "We hope for a higher rate from the Otto cooperation."

Otto is of specific interest to Tellit because the majority of its customers are women -- who are regarded as "better risks" by motor insurers, Livonius said. In addition, mail order customers are used to buying goods and services by mail or phone.
In addition to special prices for women drivers, Tellit offers a rebate for drivers parking their cars overnight in garages, and 30 percent for a second car in the family.
Tellit was set up in 1994 and is fully owned by Colonia Konzern Holding, which in turn is controlled by UAP of France.
The direct-selling insurer currently has 70,000 customers in motor insurance. In early 1996, it started to sell other private insurance lines, too, and founded its own life insurance subsidiary.
The company has no salesmen, it operates only via mailshots and telephone. In 1995, premium income was 25 million marks, for 1996, Sticker expects 65 million marks.
